summary: Victor L. Trinkala is a person who enlisted in the U.S. Army underage. Several documents detail an investigation into his enlistment and subsequent discharge. He claimed to be 17 when he enlisted, but his records incorrectly stated his birthdate. He sought an interview to correct this. He was also investigated due to an anonymous tip suggesting he was contacted by a "Soviet Agent" because of his conscientious objector status, with the alleged intent to use him for anti-U.S. propaganda. Richard C. Nagell is mentioned as having intervened to prevent Trinkala's deployment to Vietnam and later, Trinkala stated that Nagell helped him get discharged. Interviews were conducted to assess Trinkala's character and loyalty, during which he was perceived as reluctant and evasive.
significance: Victor L. Trinkala's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his connection to Richard C. Nagell, a figure of interest in the JFK assassination investigations. The documents suggest that Nagell may have assisted Trinkala in avoiding military service, and the investigation into Trinkala's case may have been part of a broader inquiry into Nagell's activities and associations.
